summary: This is an FBI News Briefing dated July 28, 2020, covering a wide range of topics including protests, counter-terrorism, criminal investigations, and other national news. It includes a brief mention of Ghislaine Maxwell seeking to seal evidence in her case, but the document is primarily a daily news summary for FBI leadership covering various national and international events.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in the criminal investigations section as seeking to seal evidence including nude photographs and sexualized video ahead of her trial for grooming underage girls for Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the associate for whom Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly groomed underage girls for sexual abuse.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: U.S. District Judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's case, to whom Maxwell's attorneys wrote regarding sealing evidence.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Mentioned in multiple contexts: to defend the administration in congressional testimony, and in relation to the clearing of protesters from Lafayette Square on June 1, 2020.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Referenced numerous times throughout the briefing in various contexts including pandemic response, protests, and political matters.

persons.name: Robert O'Brien
persons.context: Reported to have tested positive for coronavirus and is self-isolating.

persons.name: Deborah Birx
persons.role: White House Coronavirus Task Force Coordinator
persons.context: Visited Tennessee advocating for mask-wearing and bar closures to combat COVID-19.

persons.name: Alex Azar
persons.context: Credited mask-wearing for plateauing COVID-19 cases in key states.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.context: Visited University of Miami to highlight coronavirus vaccine development.

persons.name: Larry Kudlow
persons.context: Commented on economic recovery and stimulus negotiations.

persons.name: Mitch McConnell
persons.context: Unveiled GOP coronavirus relief proposal including $1.75 billion for new FBI headquarters.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: Criticized GOP relief proposal and accused Trump of self-dealing regarding FBI headquarters funding.

persons.name: Charles Schumer
persons.context: Joined Pelosi in criticizing GOP relief proposal.

persons.name: Gregory Monahan
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to the clearing of protesters from Lafayette Square on June 1, 2020.

persons.name: Adam DeMarco
persons.context: Provided account challenging administration's explanation for clearing protesters from Lafayette Square.

persons.name: Tim Garrison
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for Western District of Missouri discussing Operation LeGend in Kansas City.

persons.name: Sally Yates
persons.context: Scheduled to testify before Senate Judiciary Committee about origins of Russia investigation.

persons.name: Carter Page
persons.context: Suing Yahoo and HuffPost parent company for defamation over Russia investigation coverage.

persons.name: Meng Wanzhou
persons.context: Fighting extradition to U.S., seeking Canadian spy agency documents related to her arrest.

persons.name: Julian Assange
persons.context: Subject of Spanish court investigation into whether he was spied on while in Ecuadorian Embassy.

persons.name: Mark Lowenthal
persons.role: Former Assistant Director of Central Intelligence
persons.context: Said intelligence analysis needs course change to meet new threats.

persons.name: John Lewis
persons.context: Civil rights icon lying in state at U.S. Capitol after his death.

persons.name: Ivanka Trump
persons.context: Helped open office dedicated to investigating cold cases involving missing and murdered Indigenous peoples.

persons.name: David Bernhardt
persons.context: Joined Ivanka Trump to open office for missing and murdered Indigenous cases.

persons.name: Najib Razak
persons.context: Convicted in first 1MDB trial for multibillion-dollar looting of state investment fund.

connections.description: Maxwell allegedly groomed underage girls for Epstein's sexual abuse according to the indictment.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case.
Barr as Attorney General defending the Trump administration's actions in various matters.
Barr spoke with Park Police leaders including Monahan before protesters were cleared from Lafayette Square.

events.title: FBI News Briefing
events.description: Daily news briefing covering protests, counter-terrorism, criminal investigations, and other national news.

events.title: Maxwell Seeks to Seal Evidence
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys filed to prevent nude photographs and sexualized video evidence from being unsealed ahead of her trial.

events.title: Lafayette Square Protest Clearing
events.description: U.S. Park Police cleared protesters from Lafayette Square near White House, with accounts challenging administration's explanation of the event.

events.title: Barr Congressional Testimony
events.description: Attorney General William Barr scheduled to testify before House Judiciary Committee on oversight of Department of Justice.

events.title: GOP Unveils Coronavirus Relief Proposal
events.description: Senate Republicans released $1 trillion coronavirus relief proposal including $1.75 billion for new FBI headquarters.

events.title: John Lewis Lies in State
events.description: Civil rights icon Rep. John Lewis lies in state at U.S. Capitol, first Black lawmaker to receive this honor.

events.title: O'Brien Tests Positive for Coronavirus
events.description: National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien tested positive for COVID-19 with mild symptoms, highest-ranking official to test positive.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell is seeking to seal evidence including nude photographs and sexualized videos ahead of her trial related to Jeffrey Epstein.
The FBI News Briefing is a daily compilation of news covering a wide range of topics beyond just Epstein-related matters.
The document reveals tensions between federal and local authorities regarding protest responses in Portland and other cities.
Senate Republicans' coronavirus relief proposal included $1.75 billion for a new FBI headquarters, which Democrats criticized as potential self-dealing by President Trump.
Multiple redacted names appear in the criminal investigations section (e.g., Adam James Young, Bryant Lamont Harris), indicating ongoing investigations where names are not fully disclosed.
